captions.text: Good morning, John.

Last time, you came to us from the beautiful
canals of Venice, Italy, and so today I come

to you from the beautiful canals of Venice,
Florida. I totally did not plan this.

John, the discussion of whether or not George
Washington was an evil person has spread like

wild fire across Nerdfighteria, spawning many
interesting and intelligent discussion both
in Your Pants and in the comments.

I like the concept of a What-if machine. Just
so that we can go back and see what happened

if we shove someone into the street, prevent
a butterfly from flapping its wings. I like

that there was a Nerdfighter called Deflin
in Your Pants who decided that we should actually

work up a list of criteria for what it takes
to get into the Evil Baby orphanage, and I

like that most of the discussion was focused
on intent. If we wanted to be good people
then, kind of, we are.

Though I don’t know that that’s precisely
true, and I start to get a little screwed

up here because I start to realize that it’s
not that important that we figure out what

makes a bad person because I know that I’m
not a bad person, and as kneehighargylesocks

pointed out in the comments, Sirius Black
did tell Harry Potter that you can’t separate

the world into good people and Death Eaters;
it’s more complicated than that. And I know

that I’m not a Death Eater, but I don’t
know that I’m not a good person, and I want

to be a good person, so I want to know what
the criteria for being a good person is. But

that’s not something that we necessarily
intrinsically know.

John, a couple years ago I sat on this very
dock right here and I talked about how objectively

bad the practice of eating meat is, and that’s
still true; the production of meat still accounts

for about the same amount of greenhouse gasses
as the transportation sector. Yes, that includes

driving. And if we took all of the edible
food that we feed to livestock in this country,

and instead of feeding it to livestock gave
it to people, no one in the world would be

hungry. And yet I still eat meat. I know that
it’s bad, but I keep doing it because I
like it.

I recently read in Good Magazine; I don’t
know if you know what Good Magazine is, but

it’s a magazine, and I recently read that
they’re challenging their readers to not

eat meat for the month of June, and so I think
I’m gonna try to do that. Uhh, though I’m

not going to succeed entirely because I’m
with my in-laws right now, and I have to eat

whatever they give me because I have to be
gracious. Also it’s really tasty. But I’m

not that likely to get really excited about
that idea, like I wanna eat meat, and so not
eating meat isn’t fun.

I do get excited about technological solutions,
like a bunch of scientists are trying to figure

out how to grow meat in a laboratory, much
more efficiently and without the need for,

uh, suffering of an animal. And everyone I
know, EVERYONE, when I tell them this idea,

they’re like “Bleurgh blurgaka blegh blerugh
bleuurgh,” and I’m like “For real? You

think that there’s something grosser than
the way we currently produce food?” Because

no, no there’s nothing grosser than the
way we currently produce food.

Also I find this hilarious - the United States
just, uh, revamped the food pyramid into a

plate in which half of the plate is vegetables
and fruits, which is fantastic. And the other

half of the plate is protein and grains. I
think that the protein is hilarious because

there’s tons of protein in vegetables and
tons of protein in grains. So what is up with

that? Why is there a protein section at all?
That would be because this whole thing is

being designed by the United States Department
of Agriculture and not the Department of Health,

and the agriculture industry of America, uh,
surprise, surprise, thrives on meat eating.

So, yeah, it’s a little bit disturbing that
the, ah, United States Department of Agriculture

is - is controlling, uh, the largest part
of our health equation, obesity being the

number one health problem in America right
now.

So Nerdfighters, if you can find it in your
heart, go a little bit vegetarian this month.

See how it takes you. Maybe you could just
be a lunchaterian, maybe you could just eat

meat on the weekends. Try it out, knowing
that denying yourself this one indulgence

actually, uh, is going to make you a little
bit better of a person, which will decrease

your chances of someone coming back in time
and robbing you from your cradle as a baby
and sending you to a Evil Baby Orphanage.

There’s links in the description with more
information on all of this stuff.
John, I’ll see you on Monday.

comments.text:
Thought I do agree (and so does statistics) that we eat way too much meat 
in our country as a whole, one person being a vegetarian or ever 1,000 
people is not really going to change anything. That cow we still be 
butchered and sold it just depends on who buys it. So if you don't someone 
else will.﻿
comments.author: LF J

comments.text:
I might eat lab grown meat, it's like just such a cool concept, I vegan and 
really don't like meat at all, but like Hank, I love cool sciency things﻿
comments.author: Louise Heiwood

comments.text:
I went vegan a year ago, basically just to try it out. I did it for both 
the animale and the environment, and before I went vegan, I really liked 
meat. Now, a year later, my taste has completely changed. I don't think 
meat is in any way appealing. Moral of the story: your taste can change 
with your diet.﻿
comments.author: MRJuggernaut66

comments.text:
Hitler was a vegetarian in the later years of his life, that doesn't make 
vegetarianism bad, and it certainly doesn't make Hitler good, but it is 
interesting to see how someone who treated other humans so badly could care 
about animals that much. He also had a lot of animal rights laws. But he 
did kill his dog with cyanide to make sure the pills worked... And some 
people really couldn't see just how crazy that guy was? The fuck is wrong 
with people... Why is *that* the first thing I thought of when I watched 
this? Oh yeah, we're talking about World War II in history. I feel a little 
better about myself now﻿

comments.text: All meat, lab-grown or otherwise, repulses me.﻿
comments.author: Ariel Leigh

I once tried not eating meat for a week. I couldn't even do it for a day. I 
love meat. :).﻿
comments.author: Hadiyah Carriere

comments.text:
If your parents are alive and you are taken from them; could you really 
still be considered an 'orphan'?﻿
comments.author: treborwu

comments.text:
Hank talking about this (in other videos as well) has made me think more 
about becoming vegetarian. I've decided that after summer, I'm gonna be 
vegetarian for as long as I can. woohoo! Go environment!﻿
comments.author: ahaha bahaha

comments.text:
It is possible to get a complete and balanced diet while eating no meat. 
Possible, but not easy. Trying to get the right fats and proteins and 
minerals from plant sources is extremely complex, and the reason for this 
is that humans aren't supposed to be herbivores, we're omnivores. Sorry, 
but there it is.

An interesting alternative not being discussed is eating LESS meat. North 
Americans, generally, eat way more meat than is needed for balanced 
nutrition. Between eating meat with every single meal and eating no meat 
ever, there is a middle ground. The larger question that interests me is, 
"Why do so many debates become a simplified all-or-nothing binary?"﻿
comments.author: Incidental Penguin

comments.text:
Not eating meat is actually pretty easy after the first month or so. After 
that, i felt sickened by the thought of eating meat﻿
comments.author: Jack Silverman

comments.text:
I don't discriminate my food into a binary system of "vegetarian" and 
"meat".  Different plant-based foods and different animal-based foods have 
different pros and cons.  Ecologically and energetically it's best to have 
a primarily plant-based diet.  Nutritionally diversity is best--even though 
plants have a broader spectrum, herbivores have done the processing that we 
can't and so many nutrients are more bioavailable in animal products. 
 Societies have survived on both extremes (almost all plant or almost all 
animal).  Ethically many people choose vegetarianism.  Realistically if you 
live in a rough geography animal products would be local and not shipped in 
via other natural resource wastage (oil).  In most of the developed world 
most fruits and veggies are imported, and that economic/cultural niche is a 
discussion in itself.  You can be vegetarian and eat the worst junk food, 
so intrinsically vegetarianism does not equal healthy.  Animal hormones 
(depending on the concentration) can easily be bad for humans, but major 
cash crops like grains require MASSIVE resources such as pesticides (bad), 
herbicides (not as bad), sucking up more water and soil nutrients than 
non-subsidized, socially-preferred crops (many a society has fallen to 
maize).  Animal waste can be a major pollutant, especially since they are 
usually raised in isolated regions where plants aren't profitable. 
 Different medical conditions vary in nutritional content 
considerably--most refining and additives come with anything grain based or 
cured, cheap meats, which is the trend in population health right now. 
 Meanwhile others benefit from the bioavailability of nutrients in eggs and 
meat, but can't process high fiber foods (or even high calcium foods) like 
broccoli.  Okay, I'll stop my thought process there.  Nutrition choices, 
even if you go with what's physically best for you and not based on what 
your ideals and emotions, are highly individual and somewhat dependent on 
geography.﻿
comments.author: Leah Markum

comments.text:
Lab grown meat sounds delicious, mainly because I am Jewish and the laws of 
kashrut would restrict me from eating something like a cheeseburger, 
however, if that meat wasn't actually from an animal but grown in a lab 
then that cheeseburger is mine!﻿
comments.author: Ben Newington

comments.text:
Soya-"meat" has already comparable concistancies like ground meat.  My wife 
figured out how to season it so I never notice any difference in spaghetti, 
hamburgers or meatballs.
Even my 19 month old treat it like meat, for some reason he doesn't enjoy 
meat like stuff so he would chew a piece and suck it dry just to spit it 
out again. In general we are not avoiding genuine meat but we reduced it 
conciously to 1-2 meals per week.
I would definitly try lab-meat to replace genuine meat. I am also convinced 
that meat produced in laboratories can be flavored, colored, shaped, etc.. 
authentical or even the way customers would desire.﻿
comments.author: M FK

comments.text:
+M FK As long as you don't tell people something is vegetarian or vegan, 
they think it's delicious. But once you've said the word vegetarian or, god 
forbid, vegan, they will never eat anything you've made ever again. I hope 
you'll go further one day. I suspect you haven't read the right book yet. 
Do you know "Eating Animals" by Jonathan Safran Foer? Makes it very, very 
easy to go vegan. Also, statements from people working in slaughterhouses: 
How many times a day they kill conscious animals or deliberately inflict 
pain on an animal by stabbing it in the eye. How the animals' screams sound 
when they realise they're about to die. How many animals die on the way to 
the slaughterhouse.
comments.author: HankaAAR

comments.text:
i think good people do bad things. i eat meat and wear leather every day 
but i'm also doing my best to not throw my cigarette buts on the street, 
hold in the smoke when i walk past others. i don't know.. ﻿

comments.text:
Do I think growing meat in a lab is gross? Of course not! Like you said

comments.text:
I am completely vegetarian, and have been for all of my life that I can

indirectly) rather than ridiculed. Thank you, Hank.﻿

comments.text:

~

comments.text: well said
comments.author: John Williamson

comments.text:
+Amiee Ann Veganism is good, perhaps even morally obligatory, but I think 
technically I disagree with all three of your points. Souls aren't real so 
animals don't have them, the planet doesn't care what we do to the 
biosphere, and cutting out as big a category as "meat" from our diets can 
nutritionally be at best a neutral change that doesn't make things worse.

comments.text: Humans no, planet yes, economy yes, animals yes.

comments.author: Logan Stewart

comments.text:
I think that lab grown meat is a fantastic idea. It would stop millions of 
animals' suffering. Apparently people are trying to figure out a way to 
kill animals for their meat in such a way that the animal doesn't feel any 
pain. They're still going to be dead! I'm all for lab grown meat.﻿
comments.author: Maia meow

comments.text:
Lab made meat sounds awesome. If lab-grown could taste as good as grass-fed

comments.author: narutardednerd

comments.text:
It's true, meat is a natural part of the diet- not completely necessary, 
but definitely important. On the other hand, the kinds of animals we 
slaughter and eat are hardly the animals we are adapted to eat, so unless 
you're doing your own hunting, as I see it the argument over whether or not 
vegetarianism is more or less natural than the modern diet is a bit of a 
wash. I'm pretty leery of the idea of lab grown meat, to be honest- not 
because I think it's worse than what we're currently doing, but because I 
have to imagine there are better alternatives. But I'm not researched 
enough on this to know what those would be.﻿
comments.author: americanslime

comments.text:
I think lab-grown meat is a great idea because innocent animals don't have 
to die for us to live and just the idea of eating animals is disgusting.﻿
comments.author: Ella The Harpy

comments.text:
There are actually other ways to farm animals for food that don't involve 
factory farming. Check out how NZ does it. Grass fed beef, to start with.﻿
comments.author: Mark Love

comments.text:
For all those saying meat eating is unhealthy, you come forward and explain 
why the Inuit in Northern Canada and Greenland has nearly no vegetables 
their entire lives, and ate near exclusively meat, and died well into their 
60s or early 70s, a very respectable age for the time. I am referring to 
the time that they did not have things like imported vegetables and fruit, 
and grains and cow milk. ﻿
comments.author: restlesswikiinfo

comments.text:
Not eating meat is unhealthy, good way to die from not receiving the proper

Plenty of unbiased studies have proven. It's a good way of dumbing down the 
population however, as our brains would begin becoming underdeveloped after 
each generation.﻿
comments.author: pugfugly1989

comments.author: pugfugly1989

comments.author: WeAreEnglishCubers

comments.text:

comments.author: pugfugly1989

comments.text:
+pugfugly1989 Carrying a child while being vegetarian, fair enough, but 
just because eating meat is natural doesn't make it morally right. Also, 
eating meat can be be bad for you as well.
comments.author: WeAreEnglishCubers

comments.text:
+WeAreEnglishCubers Those people are stupid, considering biologically, we 
are animals, who happen to be an apex predator in the majority of 
ecosystems, and are omnivorous by nature. What vegetarians do is so 
unnatural, that they shouldn't be allowed to reproduce. Not only is it 
incredibly dangerous for a child to be carried and born by a 
vegan/vegetarian, but being forced on said diet would kill the child. And 
before you say anything, yes, it's happened, multiple times.
comments.author: pugfugly1989

comments.text:
Some people would rather get sick than hurt animals. Is that hard to 
understand?
comments.author: WeAreEnglishCubers

comments.text:
+Loubna Ait Animals and plants are made of different cells, I'll let you 
google the difference between them. To answer your question, there haven't 
been too many vegan or vegetarian parents who have gotten away with a 
lifetime of that choice of diet, and have gotten away with passing those 
ideals on to their kids (
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2036671/Vegan-couple-serve-life-sentences-starving-baby-death-extreme-diet.html 
current big case about it). Anyway, studies that show meat eating people 
are healthier than vegans/vegetarians are as follows:

http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0088278 
- This is a study done in Austria, and the results are as follows: In the 
domain of health, the multivariate analysis of variance showed a 
significant main effect for the dietary habit of individuals (p = .000). 
Overall, vegetarians are in a poorer state of health compared to the other 
dietary habit groups. Concerning self-reported health, vegetarians differ 
significantly from each of the other groups, toward poorer health (p = 
000). Moreover, these subjects report higher levels of impairment from 
disorders (p = .002). Vegetarians additionally report more chronic diseases 
than those eating a carnivorous diet less rich in meat (p = .000; Table 2). 
Significantly more vegetarians suffer from allergies, cancer, and mental 
health ailments (anxiety, or depression) than the other dietary habit 
groups (Table 3). Subjects who eat a carnivorous diet rich in meat more 
often report urinary incontinence (p = .023). No differences between 
individuals consuming different forms of diet were found regarding their 
vascular risk (p = .150; Table 2).
comments.author: pugfugly1989

comments.text:
are you sure that you can only find fatty-acids and vitamins in meat? Why 
did you list cells? Vegetables and fruit are made of cells. You seem to be 
really sure andI don't think that I'm in the position to tell you that you 
are wrong, so I would like you to name those studies you've been talking 
about. Also, answer me one question: How do vegetariens exist (without 
becoming underdeveloped)?
comments.author: Loubna Ait

comments.text:
I'm SO SO SO behind lab grown meat. In fact, i'm making it a personal goal 
to try and fund that when i'm a little older. Also, yes, eating meat is bad 
for the planet and not so great for our health... But I just can't seem to 
stop doing it. I've tried and tried and I always feel wrong whenever i do 
the vegan thing and i always just end up slipping up on the veggie thing 
anyway. That said, i try and limit my meat and dairy intake as much as 
possible. In this one respect, yes, i'm a bad person because i'm 
sacrificing the greater good of the world for my own selfish gain.﻿
comments.author: Robert Langford

comments.text:
I do not find lab-grown meat disgusting, because all in all it is the same 
components matched up in the same way (aka the same thing)
I do, however, understand why some might find it disturbing, because of the 
'unnatural' process. It might seem a bit frankensteiny﻿
comments.author: Sofie Rauff

comments.text:
If we didn't eat meat... Would we no longer feed cows and pigs? If we only 
ate vegetables.. Would Cows and pigs no longer exist?

(These questions are not opinionated, one way or another.. I'm purely 
curious, before I make my decision).﻿
comments.author: Trenton Sabo

comments.text:
First of all, I estimate the chances of everyone on earth becoming 
completely vegetarian are zero. Best case scenario it becomes more of  a 
luxury item
But the hypothetical is more interesting, and I think that as long as 
there's a phase-out time the animals will become exotic enough that thy 
will be featured in zoos, petting zoos, and historical villages.
comments.author: Kayla B

comments.text:
Task one: Become vegetarian... uh well I've been vegetarian since birth
Task two: become vegan... I became vegan a few months ago and at the start 
it was hard, and I slipped up a few times, but after a while things like 
(dairy) ice cream don't taste as good, its also surprising how much is 
actually vegan.     ﻿
comments.author: cardbord box

comments.text:
I decided to try being vegetarian for a few weeks. My biggest fear was that 
it would inconvenience other people. What if friends want to go to a 
restaurant without any vegetarian choices? I ended up having a few 
temptations/cheats during those weeks, ate a chicken burger at one point 
and pizza which obviously had to have pepperoni on it. But then I just 
kinda kept going with it...

That was 6 years ago. Today not even the smell of bacon temps me. I've 
heard all kinds of weird comments, like people saying that I probably lack 
nutrients or that they were vegetarian for 2 months and their toenails 
started falling off so it's impossible that I've never cheated in 6 years. 

I didn't do it to save the animals, or because someone told me to try it. I 
did it because I didn't like being in denial. Eating sausages because i 
like the taste without thinking about the flesh and veins and guts which 
they contain. Eventually I was no longer able to separate the gore from the 
nice plastic-wrapped food. If you know and have seen all that and you're 
fine with it, great! Me, I can't do it.﻿
comments.author: Vincent T.

comments.text:
You're not a bad person, and I think lab-grown meat is gross because it 
makes me think of Cloud Atlas.....﻿
comments.author: Miccella Staiano

comments.text:
I am really looking forward to lab-grown meat. Insufficient protein 
triggers my depression, and although I've tried, it's hard for me to meet 
my particular dietary protein requirements on a vegetarian diet (and also I 
really like meat), but I have trouble reconciling that with my desire to 
not be cruel to animals and not contribute to environmental degradation.  

Vat-grown meat would solve all of that. And is far less disgusting than 
killing live animals to obtain meat. ﻿
comments.author: Raina Ramsay

comments.text:
I obviously do not know all the details of your dietary restrictions but if 
it's protein you're worried about you should know that there are lots of 
ways to get sufficient protein in a plant-based diet. Reply or message to 
me and I can send you sources/advice for finding protein outside of meat if 
you're interested.
comments.author: showrespectplease

comments.text:
1: I'd be biased in replying to that, since i am the same way ;)

2: No, as you mention; the way we produce meat is already pretty disgusting.
Personally, i'm considering trying out something like Soylent* , the only 
reason i haven't taken the plunge, is because i'm unsure of how my 
digestive system will handle and/or be afffect by a liquid diet.﻿
comments.author: Patrick Hansen

comments.text: challenge accepted﻿
comments.author: Brielle Hewes

comments.text:
Of course you are not a good person! There is none good, no, not one. You 
have lied in your life. you have coveted.  You have dishonored your parents 
at some point. We are all guilty of these things. And we will all be 
punished by God. Yes, you can know there is a God! The fool says in his 
heart there is no God. And the punishment He has for us is hell. But God 
came to Earth as a man to die in order to redeem us. If we walk away from 
our sins and follow Him, you will be seen as righteous in HIS eyes, and you 
will inherit eternal life.﻿
comments.author: Collin Wise

comments.text:
I'm honestly not a huge fan of meat anyway. I do eat it, but I know I could 
live without it if I weren't so lazy. And by lazy, I mean I haven't done 
the research on how to be a good vegetarian and not accidentally starve 
myself of vital nutrients. My biggest thing with eating meat is making sure 
the animal wasn't mistreated, so when I have extra money, I buy the free 
range stuff.﻿
comments.author: English3Muffin

comments.text:
As a vegetarian who has grown up eating meat and very much enjoyed 
hamburgers and hotdogs and steak, I understand how hard it can be to make a 
transition. But I encourage everyone to at least be informed of the 
disgusting way that meat is produced currently (the documentary 
'Earthlings' is graphic and hard to watch but is a good way to learn) and 
maybe then you will be more motivated to not be a part of the torture that 
the meat industry inflicts on animals.﻿
comments.author: TheTARDISCatcher

comments.text:
Unfortunately, the issue of being a vegetarian or not is not that simple. 
 If you go vegetarian for health reasons, you are faced with issues on how 
to receive enough protein to keep you full.  This is particularly a problem 
if you are very active, because protein helps build muscle.  Of course, 
there are plenty of protein substitutes, and tofu is actually rather 
delicious when prepared correctly, but if you want to raise a family with 
young boys vegetarian, you will need a substitute for the tofu, because the 
estrogen in soy will stunt their growth.  

Also, if enough people went vegetarian, what would we do with the thousands 
of animals that would not be able to be released because they are no longer 
really chickens and cows?  Would chickens and cows and pigs go largely 
extinct?  Are they already extinct in theory, and if so, does the welfare 
of those animals being raised for meat matter?﻿
comments.author: Rebecca Roberts

comments.text:
+showrespectplease Ok, so I guess that technically it is possible to be 
vegan in modern times. Good job, you have made a superior argument and 
enlightened me about new technology. I rest my case, and tip my hat.
comments.author: Collin Wise

comments.text: +Collin Wise I posted a link in my last comment to vegan D3 supplements.
comments.author: showrespectplease

comments.text:
I did say B12, but now I see that you are correct, and will stop saying 
that. However, D3. Not the mighty ducks, but the vitamin.
comments.author: Collin Wise

comments.text:
+Collin Wise What Vitamins are you referring to? if it's B12, then B12 can 
be made (and is made) from bacteria (source: 
http://www.veganhealth.org/b12/vegansources). If it's D3 supplements you're 
referring to, they also make vegan supplements for that too (source: 
http://vitashine-d3.com). Why do you think only adults can live off a vegan 
diet? Children can be vegan as well.
comments.author: showrespectplease

comments.text:
Vitamins.
Did I not explain how they kill the animals to put those proteins in the 
vitamins? Well, perhaps if you are an adult you could still live off a 
vegan diet.
comments.author: Collin Wise

comments.text:
+Collin Wise Carnosine is not "essential" to live. "If we don't, we die", 
then what do you say to the tons of vegans/vegetarians who are 80+ years 
old? And how about recent studies that indicate a plant-based diet is 
actually better for living longer? 
1.Am J Clin Nutr. 1999 Sep;70(3 Suppl):516S-524S. Mortality in vegetarians 
and nonvegetarians: detailed findings from a collaborative analysis of 5 
prospective studies. Key TJ, Fraser GE, Thorogood M, Appleby PN, Beral V, 
Reeves G, Burr ML, Chang-Claude J, Frentzel-Beyme R, Kuzma JW, Mann J, 
McPherson K.
2. Am J Clin Nutr. 1994 May;59(5 Suppl):1153S-1161S. Diet and chronic 
degenerative diseases: perspectives from China. Campbell TC, Junshi C.
3. J Nutr. 2005 Mar;135(3):556-61. The combination of high fruit and 
vegetable and low saturated fat intakes is more protective against 
mortality in aging men than is either alone: the Baltimore Longitudinal 
Study of Aging. Tucker KL, Hallfrisch J, Qiao N, Muller D, Andres R, Fleg 
JL; Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging.
4. Arch Intern Med. 2001 Jul 9;161(13):1645-52. Ten years of life: Is it a 
matter of choice? Fraser GE, Shavlik DJ.
comments.author: showrespectplease

comments.text:
All I'm saying is that it is impossible to be vegan, because carnosine 
(which comes from the latin "carnis" which means "meart") is essential for 
us to have in order to live, and our bodies do not have it, nor do other 
plants, nor can it be made in a lab, but other animals can manufacture it 
in their bodies, and then we can eat those animals. If we dont, we die.
Sorry, maybe i should have said VEGAN instead of vegetarian, although I am 
not sure if there is anyway to get the carnosine without eating the meat.
comments.author: Collin Wise

comments.text:
+Collin Wise hey Collin. There are reasons to go vegetarian for health 
reasons.... Animal protein and cholesterol is directly correlated with 
increased risk of heart disease, obesity and cancer (as Hank alludes to in 
the video, also see my citations below)*. 

You're correct about B12 and D3. We need those. Although with 15 minutes of 
sunlight you get enough daily D, and B12 can be obtained with a daily 
supplement, or by eating a slight bit of dairy each day. Happy to answer 
any other questions @castig 

*Citation: The China Study (book), Forks Over Knives (documentary film)
comments.author: Chris Castiglione

comments.text:
There is no such thing as going vegetarian for health reasons. There are 
essential nutrients that you need to live which can only be found in meat, 
such as enzymes like creatine, carnosine, and DHA. Also vitamins B12 and D3 
are obtained through eating meat. No culture in the world has ever gone 
vegan because without these, you will die. Even if you take supliments for 
these pills, they still kill animals to get them in the pills, just as if 
you were eating them, only more of the animal is unused because now the 
meat is inedible.
comments.author: Collin Wise

comments.text:
About the protein thing - 97% of Americans eat too much protein. For some 
reason people freak out about vegetarians not getting enough protein, but 
that really isn't a problem at all. The average person needs about 42 
grams, and the average omnivore gets about 80. The average vegetarian gets 
around 76.

However, with other nutrients that Americans are lacking significantly in 
(like fiber), vegetarians are doing significantly better.

I'm not saying vegetarianism is necessarily right for everyone, but it 
definitely does have it's health benefits.
comments.author: Beth H.

comments.text:
I see no problem with eating meat created in a laboratory. Unless of coarse 
it has some horrible affect like making everybody stupid like in that one 
episode of Eureka.﻿

comments.author: WhimsicalBlades

comments.text:
I so want to see lab grown meat!! Even if its disgusting and I don't 
actually want to eat it, I want to see it.

On the topic of baby orphanageing, I feel like people can't be blamed for 
going along with society's status quo if they don't know it's wrong. I 
don't think it is fair to write of the entirety of our history because they 
were racist or sexist or homophobic or otherwise prejudiced (and they all 
were) because that's because the ideas of otherwise were not known to them. 
In the same way, I hope my ancestors won't think harshly of me for the 
things I do not know are inherently wrong when they look back. That is not 
to say we should not pity those who were oppressed, just that the blame was 
not with the entire culture.

This means Hitler should be sent to the baby orphanage because what he did 
was wrong and abhorrent to the people who witnessed it then. George 
Washington owned slaves, but so did every other rich, white American. He 
was at fault don't get me wrong, I'm not condoning Slavery, but he was 
wrong as part of a group. The blame should be divided amongst all the other 
offender, an entire society, truth be told.

Feel free to disagree Nerdfighters, I love a good debate.

(Plus I know there is no verb to orphanage)﻿
comments.author: Matthew Oulton

comments.text:
O so thats why Hitler din't go to the evil baby orphange, he was a

comments.text:

comments.author: SparkySywer

comments.text:
Hitler wasn't a vegetarian, he ate pig every day for lunch. His 
vegetarianism label was maybe propaganda spread by his people to make him 
seem more moral and likable, or just from a time when he was told to lay 
off eating so much meat by a doctor.  In some of his bios, it talks about 
his love of sausages etc. He are a lot of ham/pig etc.which is considered 
'white meat' and therefore not considered as meaty by some people. He 
wasn't a vegetarian, and didn't care about animal rights (obviously) 
http://www.naturalnews.com/025163_Hitler_vegetarian_vegetarianism.html
comments.author: Zoe Vickers

comments.text: At least he was a vegitarian and not a vegetarian.
comments.author: SparkySywer

comments.text:
I think it is so hypocritical how we say slavery is bad and all of these 
other things are bad and completely ignore the wrongs that we do now. We 
WERE bad but NOW we're good. the educations system teaches us to criticize 
wrongs in the past that we all agree with but doesn't address the potential 
wrongs that we are currently doing. The exact same justification thing 
happened with slavery "well slaves, they just aren't people. Their pain 
doesn't count therefore it's ok. It's just their natural condition." The 
same thing happens with meat we think it is just ok because they are 
animals therefore they are inferior based our standers on worth. Because 
they are inferior we can subject them to what ever we like because their 
pain... meh.. it doesn't really matter. It is the same double standard that 
decides that worth somehow translates to how much pain animals/people 
endure. I am taking US history and it is unsettling how much the meat 
industry and slavery parallel each other. ....and yet I still eat meat... I 
am a Thomas Jefferson...﻿

comments.author: rainbowkat1516

comments.text:
I don't know if abstaining from eating meat would transfer into solving any 
of the world's malnourished. I imagine farmers would probably just produce 
less grain without people buying it for livestock. Even if we had a surplus 
that doesn't mean we can easily send it to the places that need it﻿
comments.author: Ben Jones

comments.text:
+Lord Voldomort Actually, depending on the source of your estimates, it 
takes at least 8x as much land and 90x as much water to produce a pound of 
beef as it does for wheat even though beef only provides 1.4x as much 
nutrition. The scariest statistic is that calorie for calorie, it takes 27x 
as much energy to produce beef as it does wheat (due to transporting so 
much wheat to the cattle farm and housing and slaughtering them). We will 
have to increase the amount of food for human consumption, but overall 
production will decrease. Lab meat is a great idea since most people don't 
want to be vegetarian and the nutrients it provides mean you don't have to 
watch your diet as closely.
comments.author: Kayla B

comments.text:
+Kayla B Well if we were to phase out of eating meat we would have to make 
up for that gap in our diets that we would have to contribute to fill with 
more land dedicated to farming. You must realize that the people who used 
to eat meat would use all the grain being fed to the animals to feed 
themselves in place. So as far as dropping meat to drop consumption of 
edible goods is not a viable solutions. If you want to increase food 
production and decrease land consumption lab grown meat is definitely needs 
to be there to fill the gap made by animals currently.
comments.author: Lord Voldomort

comments.text:
But even if we assume none of the extra grain is sent overseas, it will use 
far less water, gasoline, pesticides, herbicides, fertilizer, and land, 
which can be returned to the natural ecosystem. Before someone brings up an 
argument about farmers loosing their livelihood, let me say that it's a lot 
easier to find another job than another planet.
comments.author: Kayla B

comments.text: It's now just meat. But it includes legumes and nuts. ﻿
comments.author: Becca Moses

comments.text:
Eating meat is not inherently bad, because not all meat is made through the 
huge, horrible system that Hank is focusing on. Eating meat through local, 
humane farms (given that you can find them) is totally ethically 
acceptable.﻿
comments.author: Henry Krider

comments.text:
It is certainly better because the animals suffer less in their, still very 
short, lives (they all get killed during adolescence), but do always 
remember that the farmers we call humane still cut off their chicken's 
beaks/castrate their pigs without making sure they are unconscious, and 
that all of them bring their animals to the same slaughterhouses that the 
factory farmers work with. Also, the farming you describe makes up about 1% 
of all the meat produced in the US each year. So, yes, I would always 
enocurage people do buy their meat from local, "humane" farmers, but I also 
encourage them to remember that these farmers still aren't the one's you 
see in children's books.
comments.author: HankaAAR

comments.text:
I think lab grown meat sounds disgusting. We can grow the meat part of meat

Replicator! Oh and Synthohol....Synthohol would be a fantastic invention! ﻿

comments.text:
Replicators....Synthohol, and holodecks...that is what would make life in 
this world perfect. The replicators can recycle items such as plates and 
cups, synthohol isn't really a way for people to get drunk (except for in 
Voyager) and a holodeck (is that spelled right?) would be an awesome way to 
spend time and have like school field trips and explore different life 
experiences like skydiving without dying...oh oh and all that nifty medical

comments.author: TheMsYvie

comments.text:
I am not bad because I eat meat. The perfect human diet is low in 
carbohydrates. It is high im protein and fat. Carbohydrates, particularly 
processed carbs are the biggest culprit in the so called obesity epidemic. 
Now those things being said I should go on to say that I don't mean a 
person should eat meat at every meal. A goodly amount of the protein we eat 
should come from nuts. We as a species should eat a lot less carbohydrates. 
We should eliminate sugar from our diets completely. Eating honey and fruit 
only occasionally. Green leafy vegetables, coniferous vegetables and only 
those root vegetables that can be (but don't have to be) eaten raw should 
be comsumed. Still unless we're talking cannibalism nothing we eat makes us 
bad. Veganism isn't the moral high ground they just act like it is. ﻿
comments.author: hoosierarcher

comments.text: Lol
comments.author: daydodog

comments.text:
I feel like this argument has brought many questions to my mind, especially 
with my life as of late. I have a cousin who actually went vegan, although 
she still eats things that have eggs, and occasionally has a hamburger, and 
stuff like that. She obviously isn't a full-on vegan, but she definitely 
does not enjoy having a huge T-bone steak every single day (not that 
I/anyone I know does that). I think that if people were to consider the 
vegan lifestyle, they should be more like that. Which is to say, don't 
totally banish all meat in every form out of your life. Human beings are 
omnivores, meaning we are made to eat both plants, AND animals. Yes, I 
don't like watching things get shot, but before technology, and before the 
better part of our society, people lived off BOTH meat AND 
vegetables/fruits. I'm definitely not a scientist. I have not gone to 
school, nor have I studied these things on my own. However, my belief is 
that people should just live balanced. Obviously people will continue to do 
as they will, just as I will continue to do as I will, but I feel as if 
things would be a lot easier if we could all just agree that as omnivores, 
neither way is wrong. That being said, I am disgusted at the myriad of 
drugs that are currently being stuck into the animals that we eat in order 
to make them bigger. In that sense, I feel like eating meat is probably 
more dangerous than it was a century ago... Lol maybe I should just go live 
on a farm XD
comments.author: Connie Marie

comments.text:
That is untrue. The biggest contributor to the obesity epidemic is 
overeating and sedentary lifestyles in approximately equal measure. The low 
carb craze is just that...a craze. Ten years from now we'll all share a 
good laugh and wonder why people bought into it while at the same time 
agreeing that eating food while doing handstands makes you much more 
healthy than people who eat right side up.
comments.author: Drew Boivie

comments.text:
I like your plan...however healthy as it is, it is unrealistic in todays 
world of fast food and frozen meals and candy and yummy fruit flavored ice 
cream. Carbs are not all bad, the major argument is in the type of carbs 
and the amount of activity a person partakes in to burn off said carbs. A 
person who sits in a cubical all day does not need to eat subs and tons of 
pasta because they do not use the energy that the carbs give and thus it 
turn into fat through a long and complex journey that I am sure Hank can 
explain.
comments.author: TheMsYvie
